p: The variability of EO composition of ten accessions of P. cattleyanum (nine from leaves and one from fruits) were classified into different chemical profiles. In all samples, at least one constituent with caryophyllane skeleton was identified. Three profiles of leaves oils were characterized only by caryophyllane-type constituents: E-caryophyllene (31.5%) in profile I from French Polynesia [ 36]; E-caryophyllene (59.9%) and caryophyllene oxide (5.4%) in profile II from USA [ 37]; E-caryophyllene (59.6%), caryophyllene oxide (18.2%) and Z-caryophyllene (6.4%) in profile III from south Brazil [ 38]. Profile IV oil from the USA was rich in E-caryophyllene (59.0%), followed by acyclic monoterpenes, such as α-pinene (13.2%) and myrcene (11.3%), respectively [ 39]. Profile V oil from southeastern Brazil was characterized by the E-caryophyllene (23.4%), caryophyllene oxide (11.5%), and α-pinene (11.3%) [ 22]. Profile VI oil from Egypt was rich in E-caryophyllene (28.8%), α-pinene (28.0%), myrcene (13.4%), and trans-β-ocimene (5.3%) [ 40].
